 And just how does government force the choice? What goverment in the US tells gays they can't be gay? Sodomy laws have been struck down, so that no longer applies.
dsadevil

Special Privileges? No, I'm not in favor of those (for anyone, race, religion, whatever). But the right to be equal under the law is not a privilege. The right to decide with whom you want to have the law recognized as your lawful partner is not a privilege either. The right to be free from discrimination is not a privilege either.
 
 
And just how does government force the choice? What goverment in the US tells gays they can't be gay? Sodomy laws have been struck down, so that no longer applies.
 
 
 And I'm sure you were at the forefront in the fight for that ruling. Meanwhile, laws against allowing civil unions for gay couples still exist, the federal Defense of Marriage Act still exists. As a nation, the last few years have yielded great progress. But that doesn't mean we are all the way there. You can't deny gays equal rights b/c you assert they want special rights as well.
ApathySam

WarriorPoet,
 
 Affirmative action is a different debate. For the record, I don't agree with it, and the "in your face" kind of gay rights marching/protesting/whatever irritates me too. But like dsadevil said, special privileges are different from equal treatment. Marrying, adopting, inheritence, job discrimination protection, and health insurance, to name a few, are not special privileges. Everyone else has those rights, gay people do not.
 
 The choice argument is also very distracting... I tend to get absorbed by it and forget a very important thing: Choice is only relevant in the religious debate over homosexuality (and even then, sometimes it's not). As far as government and law goes, personal preferences are clearly protected.
 
 I would agree that if Sally came out with proof that homosexuality is a choice, her research would be heavily criticized and closely scrutinized. On the flip side of the coin, though, it would be accepted almost immediately by half the population with only a cursory glance. Still, it's a scenario I have a hard time imagining.. There's a reason that denial's such a major stage for almost everyone who is homosexual. Why would someone choose a lifestyle that so many people still don't accept? And if they did choose it, why would they deny it for years and pretend it doesn't exist?
ApathySam

One more thing, WarriorPoet,
 
 I apologize for getting heated, too. This is an issue I also get really into when debating, and it's not hard for me to get angry.
 
 Cheers,
Carman

OK. I guess I need to back off here and calm down. I am just tired of all this "in your face" from gays lately, and I am getting a little emotional. I tend to lean to the side of choice for a few reasons(religious beliefs and what I view as more proof to the choice side than the genetic side).
 
 Let me ask a question, though. If we don't know if homosexuality is by choice, or is genetic, or is biologocal, etc., should we still move ahead and make homosexuals another distinct group and start making laws to protect them and even give a head start to them (affirmative action for all the pains they have suffered through discrimination)? Should we make this leap before we know what causes homosexuality?
 
 Better yet, if Sally Scientist finds definitive proof tomorrow that homosexuality is nothing but environmental, how far do you think her research will survive? How long before she is "silenced" by the media, other scientists scared of the pressure, etc.?

 
 I believe that they deserve equal rights, but I don't think it would be fair to give them special treatment. I'm blonde and I hear a lot of blonde jokes, but I don't expect special treatment because of that.
 To be honest, I am not really sure what causes homosexuality. I know there is research to suggest that it is genetic, but personally I don't know, so I don't want to say that I KNOW it is genetic, and I don't know that it is environmental, so I don't want to say that either.
 If you have any research to back your claim that it's environmental, I'd like to see that, just so I can look at both sides of it. But I think you are entitled to your opinion that it is enviromental, and I think that anyone who thinks it is genetic is entitled to that opinion as well.
 And if I came across as being 'emotional', I'm sorry!! I really wasn't being that way, at least not on purpose... :)
